Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[♪ INTRO ♪] Parents have a bunch of catchphrases. Things like, “Don’t eat with your mouth
open” or “Don’t run with scissors." Another one you might recognize is “don’t sit too close to the TV; it’ll hurt your eyes." But it turns out that the science behind that one isn’t actually true—at least, not anymore. Your eyes might start to feel tired, but the
TV won’t actually hurt them. That idea came from some faulty televisions back in the late 1960s. About 50 years ago, General Electric accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe. Talk about a manufacturing flaw. Like most other old, boxy TVs, the GE ones used cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, to generate a picture. Inside the glass vacuum tubes, electrons were fired at a screen covered in red, green, and blue phosphors, a type of material that glows when hit by something like electrons. And when fast-moving electrons strike something in a vacuum, it generates X-rays. To protect people from this radiation, engineers mixed lead into the glass ray tubes— but this batch of GE televisions was produced with faulty tubes. Two pieces were misaligned, which meant that the X-rays were deflected out of the bottom of the TV set and toward the ground right under
the television, where some kid was probably singing along to The Flintstones theme song. A recall notice estimated that sitting under the TV for a total of 40 hours would expose someone to so much radiation that their skin would turn red and painful. Which is... not great. But the good news is it doesn’t seem like
anyone was hurt. Thankfully, modern LCD TVs don’t emit harmful radiation at all, so you can sit as close as you want. But if you do spend too much time binging Netflix, you might still develop a headache. If you stare at the TV—or basically anything, including a book or your smartphone—for too long, you can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain. After a while, whatever you’re staring at
will start to get wobbly and fuzzy, and you might get a headache or feel tired. Fortunately there’s an easy fix: Go do something else, or at least just look away for a few seconds. Now, kids can focus on things close up much better than adults can without developing eye-strain, which is why they tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens—like televisions. And, in the 1960s, that might have been a
problem. But today, kids won’t get radiation burns
by doing it, no matter what their parents say. So the next time you’re in the mood for
a vintage movie marathon, you can sit wherever you’d like. But when Netflix asks you if you’re still
watching, it might be time to give your eyes a break. Thanks for asking, and thanks to all of our patrons on Patreon who keep the answers coming. If you’d like to submit a question to be
answered, you can go to patreon.com/scishow. [♪ OUTRO ♪]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fifty years ago, General Electric accidentally released what kind of televisions?
Options: A. TVs that showed no color, B. Black and white TVs that emitted heat, C. Color TVs that emitted X-rays that were unsafe, D. TVs with plastic vacuum tubes
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason for the concern about sitting too close to the TV in the 1960s? Options: A. The TV emitted a loud noise., B. The TV emitted X-rays from faulty televisions., C. The TV had a manufacturing flaw that caused it to overheat., D. The TV was too big and took up too much space. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of material glows when hit by electrons in a cathode ray tube (CRT)? Options: A. Phosphors., B. Lead., C. Glass., D. Vacuum. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the estimated exposure time for someone to experience skin redness and pain due to radiation from a faulty TV? Options: A. 10 hours., B. 20 hours., C. 40 hours., D. 60 hours. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a possible consequence of staring at a screen for too long? Options: A. Improved eye sight., B. Reduced eye strain., C. Tired eyes and headaches., D. Increased focus. Correct Option: C
Question 5: Why do kids tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens? Options: A. Because they are too lazy to move away., B. Because they can focus on things close up better than adults., C. Because they like to watch TV., D. Because they are too old to sit close to screens. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What type of TVs do not emit harmful radiation? Options: A. CRT TVs., B. LCD TVs., C. Plasma TVs., D. LED TVs. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a suggested solution to prevent eye strain when watching TV? Options: A. Take a break and look away from the screen., B. Keep watching TV without taking a break., C. Change the channel., D. Turn up the volume. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the cause of the faulty production of the GE televisions? Options: A. A manufacturing flaw., B. A design error., C. A lack of quality control., D. A software issue. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is a possible consequence of not taking breaks when watching TV? Options: A. Improved focus., B. Reduced eye strain., C. Tired eyes and headaches., D. Increased productivity. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a recommended action to take when you're tired of watching TV? Options: A. Keep watching TV., B. Take a break and do something else., C. Change the channel., D. Turn up the volume. Correct Option: B
Question 11: What type of TVs were responsible for emitting X-rays in the 1960s? Options: A. LCD TVs., B. CRT TVs., C. Plasma TVs., D. LED TVs. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the result of the faulty production of the GE televisions? Options: A. The TVs were too big and took up too much space., B. The TVs had a manufacturing flaw that caused them to overheat., C. The TVs emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe., D. The TVs were too expensive. Correct Option: C
Question 13: Why didn't anyone get hurt from the faulty GE televisions? Options: A. Because they were turned off., B. Because they were not used for a long time., C. Because there was a recall notice., D. Because the radiation was not strong enough. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a benefit of modern LCD TVs? Options: A. They are cheaper than CRT TVs in the 1960s., B. They are more expensive than TVs in the 1960s., C. They do not emit harmful radiation., D. They are too big and take up too much space. Correct Option: C
Question 15: Why do kids get in the habit of sitting close to screens? Options: A. Because they are too lazy to move away., B. Because they can focus on things close up better than adults., C. Because they like to watch TV., D. Because they are too old to sit close to screens. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 12. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the type of faulty televisions released by General Electric fifty years ago. The correct option in Question 12, "The TVs emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe," is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Color TVs that emitted X-rays that were unsafe." 

Although the wording is not identical, the content and intent of the two questions are the same, making Question 12 the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[♪ INTRO ♪] Parents have a bunch of catchphrases. Things like, “Don’t eat with your mouth
open” or “Don’t run with scissors." Another one you might recognize is “don’t sit too close to the TV; it’ll hurt your eyes." But it turns out that the science behind that one isn’t actually true—at least, not anymore. Your eyes might start to feel tired, but the
TV won’t actually hurt them. That idea came from some faulty televisions back in the late 1960s. About 50 years ago, General Electric accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe. Talk about a manufacturing flaw. Like most other old, boxy TVs, the GE ones used cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, to generate a picture. Inside the glass vacuum tubes, electrons were fired at a screen covered in red, green, and blue phosphors, a type of material that glows when hit by something like electrons. And when fast-moving electrons strike something in a vacuum, it generates X-rays. To protect people from this radiation, engineers mixed lead into the glass ray tubes— but this batch of GE televisions was produced with faulty tubes. Two pieces were misaligned, which meant that the X-rays were deflected out of the bottom of the TV set and toward the ground right under
the television, where some kid was probably singing along to The Flintstones theme song. A recall notice estimated that sitting under the TV for a total of 40 hours would expose someone to so much radiation that their skin would turn red and painful. Which is... not great. But the good news is it doesn’t seem like
anyone was hurt. Thankfully, modern LCD TVs don’t emit harmful radiation at all, so you can sit as close as you want. But if you do spend too much time binging Netflix, you might still develop a headache. If you stare at the TV—or basically anything, including a book or your smartphone—for too long, you can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain. After a while, whatever you’re staring at
will start to get wobbly and fuzzy, and you might get a headache or feel tired. Fortunately there’s an easy fix: Go do something else, or at least just look away for a few seconds. Now, kids can focus on things close up much better than adults can without developing eye-strain, which is why they tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens—like televisions. And, in the 1960s, that might have been a
problem. But today, kids won’t get radiation burns
by doing it, no matter what their parents say. So the next time you’re in the mood for
a vintage movie marathon, you can sit wherever you’d like. But when Netflix asks you if you’re still
watching, it might be time to give your eyes a break. Thanks for asking, and thanks to all of our patrons on Patreon who keep the answers coming. If you’d like to submit a question to be
answered, you can go to patreon.com/scishow. [♪ OUTRO ♪]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Modern LCD TVs emit harmful radiation. True or false?
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason for the concern about sitting too close to the TV in the 1960s? Options: A. The TV emitted a loud noise., B. The TV emitted X-rays from faulty televisions., C. The TV had a manufacturing flaw that caused it to overheat., D. The TV was too big and took up too much space. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of material glows when hit by electrons in a cathode ray tube (CRT)? Options: A. Phosphors., B. Lead., C. Glass., D. Vacuum. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the estimated exposure time for someone to experience skin redness and pain due to radiation from a faulty TV? Options: A. 10 hours., B. 20 hours., C. 40 hours., D. 60 hours. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a possible consequence of staring at a screen for too long? Options: A. Improved eye sight., B. Reduced eye strain., C. Tired eyes and headaches., D. Increased focus. Correct Option: C
Question 5: Why do kids tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens? Options: A. Because they are too lazy to move away., B. Because they can focus on things close up better than adults., C. Because they like to watch TV., D. Because they are too old to sit close to screens. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What type of TVs do not emit harmful radiation? Options: A. CRT TVs., B. LCD TVs., C. Plasma TVs., D. LED TVs. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a suggested solution to prevent eye strain when watching TV? Options: A. Take a break and look away from the screen., B. Keep watching TV without taking a break., C. Change the channel., D. Turn up the volume. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the cause of the faulty production of the GE televisions? Options: A. A manufacturing flaw., B. A design error., C. A lack of quality control., D. A software issue. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is a possible consequence of not taking breaks when watching TV? Options: A. Improved focus., B. Reduced eye strain., C. Tired eyes and headaches., D. Increased productivity. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a recommended action to take when you're tired of watching TV? Options: A. Keep watching TV., B. Take a break and do something else., C. Change the channel., D. Turn up the volume. Correct Option: B
Question 11: What type of TVs were responsible for emitting X-rays in the 1960s? Options: A. LCD TVs., B. CRT TVs., C. Plasma TVs., D. LED TVs. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the result of the faulty production of the GE televisions? Options: A. The TVs were too big and took up too much space., B. The TVs had a manufacturing flaw that caused them to overheat., C. The TVs emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe., D. The TVs were too expensive. Correct Option: C
Question 13: Why didn't anyone get hurt from the faulty GE televisions? Options: A. Because they were turned off., B. Because they were not used for a long time., C. Because there was a recall notice., D. Because the radiation was not strong enough. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a benefit of modern LCD TVs? Options: A. They are cheaper than CRT TVs in the 1960s., B. They are more expensive than TVs in the 1960s., C. They do not emit harmful radiation., D. They are too big and take up too much space. Correct Option: C
Question 15: Why do kids get in the habit of sitting close to screens? Options: A. Because they are too lazy to move away., B. Because they can focus on things close up better than adults., C. Because they like to watch TV., D. Because they are too old to sit close to screens. Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

**Question 6: What type of TVs do not emit harmful radiation? Options: A. CRT TVs., B. LCD TVs., C. Plasma TVs., D. LED TVs. Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks whether modern LCD TVs emit harmful radiation, and the generated MCQ asks what type of TVs do not emit harmful radiation, with LCD TVs being the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. Wild banana plants are native to_____?
Options: A. South America, B. Southeast Asia, C. South Asia, D. both B and C
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why bananas are not a long-lasting crop at SciShow HQ? Options: A. They are difficult to store., B. They are not healthy and packed with nutrition., C. They are gone as soon as they can be bought., D. They are not a favorite among employees. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the demise of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was too expensive to produce., B. It was too small in size., C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop., D. It was not a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why are bananas sterile mutants? Options: A. Because they are not exposed to sunlight., B. Because they are not watered regularly., C. Because the seeds have pretty much stopped existing., D. Because they are not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main advantage of the Cavendish banana variety compared to the Gros Michel variety? Options: A. It is more expensive to produce., B. It is smaller in size., C. It is more resistant to the Panama disease., D. It is less popular among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 5: If the Cavendish banana variety becomes extinct, what might replace it? Options: A. The Gros Michel variety., B. Genetically engineered bananas with immunity to Panama disease., C. Wild banana plants., D. Other cultivated banana varieties. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main concern about the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is not a popular choice among consumers., C. A global monoculture of genetically identical individuals makes it vulnerable to disease., D. It is not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can scientists and growers protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. By creating genetically identical bananas., B. By destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., C. By genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main lesson learned from the Gros Michel debacle? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. The Gros Michel variety was too expensive to produce., C. Infected fields should be quickly destroyed and new crops grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., D. The Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main reason why scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Because it is a popular choice among consumers., B. Because it is a favorite among growers., C. Because it is vulnerable to disease and may become extinct., D. Because it is too expensive to produce. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. That the Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease., C. That scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish variety., D. That bananas are a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content of the transcript, Question 3 is the closest match. This information is related to the fact that wild banana plants are native to South and Southeast Asia and have seeds, whereas cultivated bananas do not.

Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: Why are bananas sterile mutants? 

This question is similar in content and intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the seeds in the bananas we eat today. Both questions are related to the reproductive characteristics of bananas. Although the wording is not identical, the correct option for Question 3 (C. Because the seeds have pretty much stopped existing) implies that the seeds are infertile, which is the correct answer for the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 4. Since the 1960's, all the bananas that people have eaten have been
Options: A. sterile mutants, B. the Cavendish variety, C. genetically identical to every other banana, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why bananas are not a long-lasting crop at SciShow HQ? Options: A. They are difficult to store., B. They are not healthy and packed with nutrition., C. They are gone as soon as they can be bought., D. They are not a favorite among employees. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the demise of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was too expensive to produce., B. It was too small in size., C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop., D. It was not a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why are bananas sterile mutants? Options: A. Because they are not exposed to sunlight., B. Because they are not watered regularly., C. Because the seeds have pretty much stopped existing., D. Because they are not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main advantage of the Cavendish banana variety compared to the Gros Michel variety? Options: A. It is more expensive to produce., B. It is smaller in size., C. It is more resistant to the Panama disease., D. It is less popular among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 5: If the Cavendish banana variety becomes extinct, what might replace it? Options: A. The Gros Michel variety., B. Genetically engineered bananas with immunity to Panama disease., C. Wild banana plants., D. Other cultivated banana varieties. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main concern about the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is not a popular choice among consumers., C. A global monoculture of genetically identical individuals makes it vulnerable to disease., D. It is not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can scientists and growers protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. By creating genetically identical bananas., B. By destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., C. By genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main lesson learned from the Gros Michel debacle? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. The Gros Michel variety was too expensive to produce., C. Infected fields should be quickly destroyed and new crops grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., D. The Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main reason why scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Because it is a popular choice among consumers., B. Because it is a favorite among growers., C. Because it is vulnerable to disease and may become extinct., D. Because it is too expensive to produce. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. That the Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease., C. That scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish variety., D. That bananas are a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

Correct Option: D

Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why bananas are not a long-lasting crop at SciShow HQ? Options: A. They are difficult to store., B. They are not healthy and packed with nutrition., C. They are gone as soon as they can be bought., D. They are not a favorite among employees. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the demise of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was too expensive to produce., B. It was too small in size., C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop., D. It was not a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why are bananas sterile mutants? Options: A. Because they are not exposed to sunlight., B. Because they are not watered regularly., C. Because the seeds have pretty much stopped existing., D. Because they are not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main advantage of the Cavendish banana variety compared to the Gros Michel variety? Options: A. It is more expensive to produce., B. It is smaller in size., C. It is more resistant to the Panama disease., D. It is less popular among consumers. Correct Option: C
Question 5: If the Cavendish banana variety becomes extinct, what might replace it? Options: A. The Gros Michel variety., B. Genetically engineered bananas with immunity to Panama disease., C. Wild banana plants., D. Other cultivated banana varieties. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main concern about the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is not a popular choice among consumers., C. A global monoculture of genetically identical individuals makes it vulnerable to disease., D. It is not a favorite among growers. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can scientists and growers protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. By creating genetically identical bananas., B. By destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., C. By genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main lesson learned from the Gros Michel debacle? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. The Gros Michel variety was too expensive to produce., C. Infected fields should be quickly destroyed and new crops grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock., D. The Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main reason why scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Because it is a popular choice among consumers., B. Because it is a favorite among growers., C. Because it is vulnerable to disease and may become extinct., D. Because it is too expensive to produce. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript? Options: A. That bananas are not a long-lasting crop., B. That the Cavendish variety is more resistant to disease., C. That scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish variety., D. That bananas are a popular choice among consumers. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 8
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

Correct Option: B

Considering the available options, I would recommend Question 2 as the most similar generated MCQ, although it is not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
there are 196 countries in the world
today and virtually none of them have purple on their national flag.
Throughout history, purple was never used to represent a kingdom civilization or
Empire. So what's wrong with purple? It's such a popular color today.
why would no country use it in their flag? the answer is really quite simple
purple was just far too expensive. No countries have purple on their flag
because up until the 1800s purple was worth more than its weight in gold
the color purple has been associated with royalty power and wealth for
centuries. In fact, Queen Elizabeth the first forbade anyone except close
members of the royal family to wear it. Purple's elite status stems from the
rarity and cost of the dye originally used to produce it the dye initially
used to make purple came from the Phoenician trading city of Tyre which is
now in modern-day Lebanon fabric traders obtained the dye from a small sea snail
that was only found in the tyre region of the Mediterranean a lot of work went
into producing the dye as more than 10,000 snails were needed to create just
one gram of tyree and purple since only wealthy rulers could afford to buy and
wear the color it became associated with the Imperial classes of Rome Egypt and
Persia purple also came to represent spirituality and holiness because the
ancient Emperor's kings and queens that wore the color were often thought of as
gods or descendants of the gods sometimes however the dye was too
expensive even for royalty third century Roman Emperor aurelion famously wouldn't
allow his wife to buy a shawl made from tyree and purple silk because it
literally cost three times its weight in gold
a single pound of dye cost three pounds of gold which is the equivalent of fifty
six thousand dollars today so since the sheer price of purple was so
astronomically high no one not
when the richest nations could afford to have purple on their flag the hue became
more accessible to lower-class is about a century and a half ago in 1856 18-year
old English chemist William Henry Perkin accidentally created a synthetic purple
compound while attempting to synthesize quinine an anti-malaria drug he noticed
that the compound could be used to dye fabrics so he patented the dye
manufactured it and got filthy rich purple dye was then mass-produced so
just about everybody could afford it the elite stopped valuing purple and the
status symbol faded away but the country flags remain the same since 1900 a
handful of new national flags have been designed and a few of them have opted to
use purple in their flag so don't be making any bets just yet hopefully you
found this interesting sometimes the simplest questions have the most
fascinating answers for more interesting videos like this one please subscribe

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The color purple did not represent which of the following:
Options: A. Holiness, B. Royalty, C. Spirituality, D. Generosity
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why purple is not commonly used on national flags? Options: A. Purple is a symbol of peace, B. Purple is associated with royalty and power, but was too expensive for most countries to use, C. Purple is a rare color in nature, D. Purple is a popular color among children Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the original source of the dye used to produce purple? Options: A. A type of plant, B. A type of sea snail, C. A type of metal, D. A type of animal Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, how many snails were needed to create just one gram of the dye? Options: A. 100, B. 1,000, C. 10,000, D. 100,000 Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why did Queen Elizabeth the First forbade anyone except close members of the royal family to wear purple? Options: A. Because it was a symbol of poverty, B. Because it was a symbol of royalty and power, C. Because it was a symbol of spirituality and holiness, D. Because it was a rare color in nature Correct Option: B
Question 5: Who accidentally created a synthetic purple compound in 1856? Options: A. William Henry Perkin, B. Queen Elizabeth the First, C. Emperor Aurelion, D. A Roman Emperor Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the equivalent value of a single pound of the dye in gold? Options: A. Three pounds, B. Three pounds of gold, C. Fifty-six thousand dollars, D. One hundred thousand dollars Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happened to the value of purple as a status symbol after the dye became mass-produced? Options: A. It increased, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased, D. It became more exclusive Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the relationship between the cost of the dye and the association of purple with royalty and power? Options: A. The cost of the dye had no effect on the association of purple with royalty and power, B. The cost of the dye increased the association of purple with royalty and power, C. The cost of the dye decreased the association of purple with royalty and power, D. The cost of the dye had a positive effect on the association of purple with royalty and power Correct Option: C
Question 9: How might the fact that purple is not commonly used on national flags be related to the accessibility of the dye in the past? Options: A. The fact that purple is not commonly used on national flags is unrelated to the accessibility of the dye in the past, B. The fact that purple is not commonly used on national flags is due to the fact that the dye was not accessible in the past, C. The fact that purple is not commonly used on national flags is due to the fact that the dye was expensive in the past, D. The fact that purple is not commonly used on national flags is due to the fact that the dye was accessible in the past Correct Option: C
Question 10: What might be a potential consequence of the fact that a handful of new national flags have been designed since 1900 and a few of them have opted to use purple in their flag? Options: A. The value of purple as a status symbol will increase, B. The association of purple with royalty and power will decrease, C. The cost of the dye will increase, D. The use of purple on national flags will become more widespread Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens to an organism's fur when exposed to oil?
Options: A. there is little or no effect, B. the fur of the organism usually repels the oil, C. it often becomes saturated with oil, D. organisms typically are unaffected by oil spills
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the Guimaras oil spill of 2006, according to the transcript? Options: A. The largest oil spill in the world's history, B. The worst oil spill in the Philippines' history, C. The first oil spill to use hair booms for cleanup, D. The Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska Correct Option: B
Question 2: What material did Phil McCroy use to create his hair boom invention? Options: A. Human hair, B. Pantyhose, C. Synthetic materials, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is unique about human hair when it comes to oil spills? Options: A. It absorbs water, B. It repels water, C. It is expensive, D. It is not effective Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary purpose of the Clean Wave program? Options: A. To collect and recycle human hair, B. To clean up oil spills using hair booms, C. To study the effects of oil spills on marine wildlife, D. To promote the use of synthetic materials for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: B
Question 5: What are the advantages of using hair booms for oil spill cleanup? Options: A. They are cheap and renewable, B. They are effective at cleaning up oil, C. They are easy to make, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the transcript, what was the immediate ecological impact of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill? Options: A. It killed marine wildlife and destroyed habitats and breeding grounds, B. It had no impact on marine wildlife, C. It only affected the Gulf of Mexico, D. It was contained quickly Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the danger posed by the chemicals used to clean up oil spills? Options: A. They are harmless to human health, B. They pose a danger to human health, C. They are only effective at cleaning up oil, D. They are only used in small quantities Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the potential for hair booms and hair mats to be used in oil spill cleanup in the future? Options: A. They will never be used, B. They will be used extensively in the next oil spill, C. They could be used in the future, but it's not certain, D. They are already the primary method for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the motivation behind the creation of the Clean Wave program? Options: A. To make a profit from human hair, B. To help clean up oil spills, C. To study the effects of oil spills on marine wildlife, D. To promote the use of synthetic materials for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the significance of human hair in oil spill cleanup? Options: A. It is not effective at cleaning up oil, B. It is expensive and not renewable, C. It is a cheap and renewable material that can be used to clean up oil spills, D. It is only used in small quantities Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question matches the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to understand the effect of oil on an organism's fur or hair. The correct option in Question 3, "It repels water," is related to the concept presented in the ground truth MCQ, where it is stated that an otter's fur becomes saturated with oil, implying that the oil coats the fur rather than being absorbed. This is similar to how human hair repels water and adsorbs oil, as explained in the transcript.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the Clean Wave program collect to make their oil booms?
Options: A. feathers, B. human hair, C. pet hair, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the Guimaras oil spill of 2006, according to the transcript? Options: A. The largest oil spill in the world's history, B. The worst oil spill in the Philippines' history, C. The first oil spill to use hair booms for cleanup, D. The Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska Correct Option: B
Question 2: What material did Phil McCroy use to create his hair boom invention? Options: A. Human hair, B. Pantyhose, C. Synthetic materials, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is unique about human hair when it comes to oil spills? Options: A. It absorbs water, B. It repels water, C. It is expensive, D. It is not effective Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary purpose of the Clean Wave program? Options: A. To collect and recycle human hair, B. To clean up oil spills using hair booms, C. To study the effects of oil spills on marine wildlife, D. To promote the use of synthetic materials for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: B
Question 5: What are the advantages of using hair booms for oil spill cleanup? Options: A. They are cheap and renewable, B. They are effective at cleaning up oil, C. They are easy to make, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the transcript, what was the immediate ecological impact of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill? Options: A. It killed marine wildlife and destroyed habitats and breeding grounds, B. It had no impact on marine wildlife, C. It only affected the Gulf of Mexico, D. It was contained quickly Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the danger posed by the chemicals used to clean up oil spills? Options: A. They are harmless to human health, B. They pose a danger to human health, C. They are only effective at cleaning up oil, D. They are only used in small quantities Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the potential for hair booms and hair mats to be used in oil spill cleanup in the future? Options: A. They will never be used, B. They will be used extensively in the next oil spill, C. They could be used in the future, but it's not certain, D. They are already the primary method for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: C

To study the effects of oil spills on marine wildlife, D. To promote the use of synthetic materials for oil spill cleanup Correct Option: B

It is a cheap and renewable material that can be used to clean up oil spills, D. It is only used in small quantities Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Hair is great at cleaning up oil due to the fact it is HYDROPHOBIC and BIOSORBENT. What do these two capitalized words mean?
Options: A. it removes substances and it attracts water, B. it repels water and removes substances, C. it attracts water and removes substances, D. it repels both water and other substances
Correct Option: B

This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130

freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials

voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the

gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of

material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate

the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens to plastic when it enters the ocean?
Options: A. Plastic biodegrades into tasty food for other creatures., B. Plastic breaks into small pieces that don't biodegrade and can harm other living creatures., C. Plastic disintegrates and disappears causing no harm to anything., D. Plastic is ignored by marine creatures since they know it is not food.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the primary effects of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Increased freshwater availability, B. Increased ocean temperatures, C. Decreased storm intensity, D. Increased precipitation Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is a critical service provided by mangrove forests? Options: A. Water filtration, B. Shoreline protection, C. Carbon sequestration, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Question 6: What is a benefit of protecting and restoring mangrove forests? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Decreased shoreline protection, C. Reduced risk of flooding, D. Increased biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a characteristic of coastal ecosystems? Options: A. High levels of pollution, B. Low levels of biodiversity, C. High levels of erosion, D. High levels of biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a consequence of climate change on coral reefs? Options: A. Increased coral growth, B. Decreased coral bleaching events, C. Reduced risk of coral disease, D. Widespread damage to coral ecosystems Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a necessary step to reduce the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Increase greenhouse gas emissions, B. Protect and restore natural habitats, C. Promote unsustainable coastal development practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a benefit of taking a multi-faceted approach to mitigate the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Reduced risk of coral disease, B. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, C. Decreased shoreline protection, D. Protection of coastal ecosystems and communities Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 24, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcript not available

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How is plankton related to plastic?
Options: A. Dead plankton can sink to the seafloor and transform into inedible fossil fuels from which plastics are made., B. Plastic floats while plankton sinks., C. Plankton and plastic are both biodegradable and comprise an important part of the ocean food web., D. Plastic and plankton can both photosynthesize and provide nutrition for marine animals.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the primary effects of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Increased freshwater availability, B. Increased ocean temperatures, C. Decreased storm intensity, D. Increased precipitation Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is a critical service provided by mangrove forests? Options: A. Water filtration, B. Shoreline protection, C. Carbon sequestration, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is a consequence of mangrove loss for coastal communities? Options: A. Increased storm protection, B. Decreased erosion, C. Reduced risk of flooding, D. Loss of shoreline protection Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is a significant threat to coral reefs? Options: A. Overfishing, B. Pollution, C. Coral bleaching events, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is a necessary step to mitigate the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Reduce greenhouse gas emissions, B. Protect and restore natural habitats, C. Promote sustainable coastal development practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is a benefit of protecting and restoring mangrove forests? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Decreased shoreline protection, C. Reduced risk of flooding, D. Increased biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a characteristic of coastal ecosystems? Options: A. High levels of pollution, B. Low levels of biodiversity, C. High levels of erosion, D. High levels of biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a consequence of climate change on coral reefs? Options: A. Increased coral growth, B. Decreased coral bleaching events, C. Reduced risk of coral disease, D. Widespread damage to coral ecosystems Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a necessary step to reduce the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Increase greenhouse gas emissions, B. Protect and restore natural habitats, C. Promote unsustainable coastal development practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a benefit of taking a multi-faceted approach to mitigate the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Reduced risk of coral disease, B. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, C. Decreased shoreline protection, D. Protection of coastal ecosystems and communities Correct Option: D

Question 3: What is a consequence of mangrove loss for coastal communities? Options: A. Increased storm protection, B. Decreased erosion, C. Reduced risk of flooding, D. Loss of shoreline protection Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is a significant threat to coral reefs? Options: A. Overfishing, B. Pollution, C. Coral bleaching events, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is a necessary step to mitigate the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Reduce greenhouse gas emissions, B. Protect and restore natural habitats, C. Promote sustainable coastal development practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is a benefit of protecting and restoring mangrove forests? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Decreased shoreline protection, C. Reduced risk of flooding, D. Increased biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a characteristic of coastal ecosystems? Options: A. High levels of pollution, B. Low levels of biodiversity, C. High levels of erosion, D. High levels of biodiversity Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a consequence of climate change on coral reefs? Options: A. Increased coral growth, B. Decreased coral bleaching events, C. Reduced risk of coral disease, D. Widespread damage to coral ecosystems Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a necessary step to reduce the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Increase greenhouse gas emissions, B. Protect and restore natural habitats, C. Promote unsustainable coastal development practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a benefit of taking a multi-faceted approach to mitigate the impacts of climate change on coastal ecosystems? Options: A. Reduced risk of coral disease, B. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, C. Decreased shoreline protection, D. Protection of coastal ecosystems and communities Correct Option: D
